data.text:
Vivian Host

Wonât you join me in welcoming Marc Acardipane? [applause] So, the first track I played when everyone was filtering in here was by PCP [Planet Core Productions] and it was called âWe Are From Frankfurt.â I think we should tell people a little bit about growing up in Frankfurt. Itâs gonna recur a lot in this conversation and is a pretty important part of your identity.

Tell me a little bit about the neighborhood that you grew up in and what kind of stuff you were up to when you were a teenager, letâs say 15 or 16.

Marc Acardipane

I start really early with the music when I was eight, learning classic guitar and when I was 12, also electronic guitar. 16â¦

Vivian Host

Just put the mic closer to your mouth.

Marc Acardipane

I hang around in bunkers because then you can play loud music, was interested in football, and then by 16 I start also buying drum machines, synthesizers.

Vivian Host

What was the impetus to start buying drum machines and synthesizers? Who had you heard that had one that made you want one?

Marc Acardipane

Actually, my teacher for electronic guitar, he was playing in a really bad punk band. He got the 808, he got the [JBL] MS-20, an 8-track recorder and I really liked that. But the major thing was because all my members from the band didnât wanna go the way [I did]: âLive from the music or die.â I wanted to do that, they donât. Then I thought, âOkay, with electronic music I need nobody.â

Vivian Host

And you also thought at that time or shortly after that electronic music was sort of the future of rock music in a way. Like rock music was getting to be, I donât know, this old dinosaur and electronic music was a place that you could put those same vibes.

Marc Acardipane

Itâs a generation thing but this comes a little later. When I was 16, there was no techno. Techno came out 18, 19, 20 when I was like that. Of course that was the new generation, rock & roll was over, so I see techno as the rock & roll of today, definitely.

Vivian Host

So there was music that was hard and made with synthesizers and stuff. Stuff like Belgian New Beat and EBM that you got onto at some point before techno, right?

Marc Acardipane

Yeah, I was in Majorca and there was a girl and everybody thought sheâs my sister and everybody, the others thought Iâm her brother but we never met actually and then we met and she gave me Front 242 Official Version which is a Belgian record, itâs kind of electro body music, really nice sounds, electronic. I didnât like the groove, I was more into the Detroit techno stuff which was more groovy but I didnât like the sounds of Detroit. It was not hard enough for me. So, that was the idea maybe to mix something out of that. Because we were really in the hip-hop scene at the beginning, but we mixed up breakbeats with techno sounds and rap and all the hip-hop crews â we play on battles â they thought we are totally mad because we [didnât] fit in there. And then one day, you look in the mirror, you say, âOK, Iâm white and Iâm not coming from Compton, so we need our own street music in Frankfurt,â and thatâs how hardcore techno was born.

Vivian Host

So, what were some of your favorite hip-hop artists back in those days?

Marc Acardipane

N.W.A. I got all the records, I have also the World Class Wreckinâ Cru with Dre, I got the first 12â, âThe Dope Manâ from N.W.A, and of course Public Enemy, the first record I have. Run DMC. We are based in Frankfurt, we had all the Americans there so thatâs why there was a really strong hip-hop scene.

Vivian Host

I think we can hear echoes of that same vibe thatâs in those records that you mentionedâ¦

Marc Acardipane

Definitely.

Vivian Host

Later on when we hear your music. What were the first clubs that you were going out to? I mean, there were some pretty famous clubs in Frankfurt. A place called Dorian Gray and then I guess a little later, place called The Omen. Were those places that you wouldâve been going or you were only in hip-hop shows?

Marc Acardipane

No, in the beginning at the Dorian Gray it was Friday, it was called the techno club. They played more electro body music, which I donât like except Front 242. And later, The Omen came later, I think â91 when the whole techno movement starts. Before Omen was also more commercial clubs. I didnât go to hip-hop parties, only when we played there. Too much trouble there.

Vivian Host

I donât know, you donât seem a stranger to trouble [laughter]. Weâll get to that later.

Marc Acardipane

You say that.

Vivian Host

This club Dorian Gray was kind of crazy because it was at the airport for one thing and it had a Richard Long soundsystem, so a very famous guy built the soundsystem. I was watching some videos and it looked more like a little bit fancy and more like a discotheque but also quite developed for that time in the late â80s. Did you like it there?

Marc Acardipane

Thatâs true. Yeah, of course, but I came more later so the usual Frankfurt techno weekend starts on a Friday at The Omen with Sven VÃ¤th. Then you hang out until 12 oâclock in the morning, then you try to stay awake until six, seven in the evening, then you go to bed. At four oâclock you get picked up and then we go to the Dorian Gray because at six DJ Dag took over and then it goes until 12 in the morning. Then you hang out in the park when the weather is good, whatever, then in the evening, we had this other club called XS which was a chill-out club. We have some tea and then later you go home and that was the Frankfurt weekend.

Vivian Host

Sounds pretty tight. Did you get all the guys that were in your hip-hop crew with you, did you take them over with you to the techno side?

Marc Acardipane

We were already techno. I donât know how weâd be in this... I donât know, it was an accident. I was never planning that we play on hip-hop battles. We know a lot of hip-hop people from Frankfurt, of course. They hang out in our office. We also did a label, Dope on Plastic, with them together.

Vivian Host

Iâm just wondering becauseâ¦

Marc Acardipane

There was no techno parties, so the first year we playe â I donât know if somebody knows here, Nine Inch Nails, KFMDM (Nine Inch Nails was an American group) - we played support for them, real concerts. The real [techno] parties started in â91. Then, all of the sudden we played there.

Vivian Host

I wanna show video number one. Unfortunately, we didnât get the subtitles but I think it will be fun to watch anyways.

(video: PCP interview filmed inside Music Hall in Frankfurt, January 1990)

All right, that was a video of yourself and your partner in Planet Core Productions, Thorsten Lambert, from January 1990 on German TV and Iâm sorry we donât have the subtitles. But youâre talking about how techno is the future, youâre kind of over rock & roll âcause itâs like AC/DC, Led Zeppelin â itâs not really possible to go further for you with that music. You said that punk was destructive but techno is telling us about the future, which I thought was a really interesting sentiment. The other interesting thing that happens in there, what club is that? Do you remember?

Marc Acardipane

The Music Hall in Frankfurt, we rented it to check some tracks. Thatâs why nobodyâs there.

Vivian Host

So, youâre playing to this club with no one in it but what you said is that you rented out the club just so you could go play the tracks and hear them. Speaker: Marc Acardipane

Yep.

Vivian Host

And I guess see if they were gonna work to release.

Marc Acardipane

Exactly, yeah. White labels from DAT and stuff like that.

Vivian Host

At this time, 1990, were you already DJing out in clubs?

Marc Acardipane

No, this starts more in â91. We also were not so much DJs in the beginning, we were more a live act. In the beginning we were FBI â which was Free Base International â then later PCP.

Vivian Host

Yeah, I guess I was wondering if when you finally made a record, that you gave to a local DJ? Youâre going through this process where youâre testing out your records and youâre seeing is this any good, does this need a better kick, is this strong enough to work in a club? I was wondering that and I was also wondering what peoplesâ reaction in Frankfurt was to maybe the first release on PCP.

Marc Acardipane

The first release was played by DJ Dag in the Dorian Gray [club] but much funnier story is PCP 006 which was âWe Have Arrived,â the first distorted track ever, which is also on Wikipedia. When we played the first time live, the sound engineer run to me, he say, âYouâre destroying my PA,â but he didnât know that the whole track was already distorted. Nobody heard that before. It was also in the Music Hall, it was the big rave from Sven, was the first rave in Frankfurt where we played out.

Vivian Host

This is Sven VÃ¤th that youâre talking about.

Marc Acardipane

Sven VÃ¤th. You know him? [laughter] One of the biggest DJs in the world, still.

Vivian Host

So, Sven VÃ¤th was supportive of you guys when you started.

Marc Acardipane

Yeah. His first interview on MTV, he had our member jacket on. There was only I think 11 jackets with the PCP. It was the same that N.W.A had. He did his first interview on MTV with it. He was with us in the crew, yeah.

Vivian Host

How did you meet Sven VÃ¤th for the first time or become friends with him?

Marc Acardipane

We were really wasted after a party and I was in the restaurant and he sits in front of me, it was four oâclock in the morning. I was telling him, âYouâre a great DJ, but the music you produce with the other guys,â because heâs not a producer, âit sucks.â I invited him to my studio and two weeks later, he came. I think nobody ever say that to him before because itâs more like everybody licked his ass.

Vivian Host

So he came to the studio. Did you guys make some stuff together?

Marc Acardipane

A few tracks, yeah, for my compilation Frankfurt Trax, which was on CBS at that time.

Vivian Host

There was this series, Frankfurt Trax, that you were mentioning which were these very dense compilations â 10 tunes, 12 tunes â that were really pushing this sound that you were developing. But one of the notable things about these compilations is that a lot of the tracks were produced by you guys under different names.

Marc Acardipane

Exactly. Nearly every track on this compilation is produced by me. Later, when we had some artists, there was a few. I mean, we always tried to [make it] Ttat people really believe that all these artists exist. In my head, they exist.

We had this little program on the Atari where you can make phantom pictures, so thatâs how we create our artists. Then there were things happen, like one magazine doesnât believe [us]. And then there was a guy in Italy, he pick us up from the airport and I look at him and I say to Thorsten, my partner, âDo we know him?â He looked exactly like Ace The Space (thatâs a track weâll hear later). We put him a beard on, give him the record, make a picture, and send it to the press. [laughter]

Vivian Host

Can we actually show photo number six? OK, soâ¦

Marc Acardipane

Thatâs Ace there on the right.

Vivian Host

Bottom right. Thatâs Ace the Space.

Marc Acardipane

[points to left] Thatâs Nasty Django, Lilâ Pepe Castro, and this is his father, itâs T-Bone Castro. Theyâre from Cuba and this is Marshall Masters. We had this name long before Eminem, from â90s. But really funny is you canât do girls with this program, so thatâs why we didnât have any female artists. You see T-Bone nose is a dick. Really [laughs].

Vivian Host

OK [laughter], so this program... Thatâs good. It was funny. I like it. This program was actually something people were using to make mugshots, right? Like criminal mock-ups.

Marc Acardipane

I think so. I donât know. I think so.

Vivian Host

I think that you told me that you made nearly all of these characters almost in one night. You were having a wild night withâ¦

Marc Acardipane

Itâs called the Night Where It was Bright.

Vivian Host

Why is it called that?

Marc Acardipane

I donât think I tell this here.

Vivian Host

OK, so you can ask Marc later what happened but you and Thorsten, your partner in PCP, stayed up all night long on this computer.

Marc Acardipane

Exactly.

Vivian Host

Making all these different characters.

Marc Acardipane

On the old Atari ST.

Vivian Host

And they all have different personalities for you, right?

Marc Acardipane

Yep.

Vivian Host

Can you just talk a little bit more about what kind of tunes those different people we saw make?

Marc Acardipane

It came after a while. First, you produce the track and then we sit down, âOK, what fits?â But then after a while.. Itâs like T-Bone Castro, for example â his 909, the closed hi-hat is broke. All the tracks is with a open hi-hat [laughter]. Nasty Django, it was more like the dirty, young style. It was not like I sit down and do it, but for me it was freedom. Because, I donât know, I do also The Mover. The Mover is really kind of depressive, dark but Iâm not everyday like that. One day, Iâm happy; one day, Iâm not happy. Thatâs all the characters come off. Marshall Masters is more like ravey, party. Ace the Space is a gangster â thatâs why his first track is â9mm Is A Classic.â We get also these nice shirts with âAce The Space. Whatâs the rude boy number?â With the 9mm on the back. It was a great seller.

Vivian Host

Maybe we should actually hear â9mmâ so you can hear what it sounds like. This is actually the first record I ever bought. It was a big record in Los Angeles where Iâm from. This is by Ace the Space, â9mm Is A Classic.â

(music: Ace The Space â â9mm Is A Classicâ / applause)

Hell yeah. So, this may be obvious to some people but what is that noise that weâre hearing in the beginning of that tune?

Marc Acardipane

You mean the synth?

Vivian Host

Yeah.

Marc Acardipane

Thatâs the famous âMentasmâ hoover sound coming from the MKS-50 or the Juno 2 [ed. - It was actually Juno 1] by Roland.

Vivian Host

So, kind of made popular by Joey Beltram.

Marc Acardipane

Exactly, Joey was the first one. When I heard the track, I said, âHeâs an alien. Where did he get that sound from?â This is maybe a thing that you guys donât have anymore today, there are coming sounds you heard them somewhere all the time. But with us, we heard sounds that you never heard before in the beginning. I remember when I heard âMentasmâ in the club, it was unbelievable when it hits and then the second track was âThe Dominatorâ from Human Resource and then we came with the street version, â9mm Is A Classic.â

Vivian Host

Something else is happening in this record with the sample, which is from a pretty famous hip-hop record by the 45 King. We can hear a little bit of that.

(music: 45 King - âThe 900 Number (Acapella)â)

You really worked that record for Ace The Space.

Marc Acardipane

The funny thing, I donât know if thereâs a track with a beat because I only know the acapella. We had only the record with acapella but I never heard the track to it. Is there a track?

Vivian Host

Yeah, there is a track.

Marc Acardipane

Never heard that one.

Vivian Host

Back then, obviously there were a lot of hip-hop records that came with acapellas, so samplingâ¦

Marc Acardipane

Every record on the B-side was always the acapella.

Vivian Host

Itâs so different now, the hip-hop artists kind of gathered that they donât want their stuff sampled anymore. But back thenâ¦

Marc Acardipane

Nobody cares. Even Chuck D., I remember he was saying in an interview, âEverybody can sample our stuff,â because hip-hop is based on samples so why they should complain if somebody else sample it. I never had any trouble and I sample a lot.

Vivian Host

Well, youâre one of the lucky ones then. So, what did you have in your studio back in 1989?

Marc Acardipane

â89â¦

Vivian Host

What were all these early PCP tracks made on?

Marc Acardipane

In the beginning, it was only the [Emu] Emax, emulator sampler with a half megabyte of sampling time. Itâs a lot. And a 909, thatâs it. And a cheap Roland mixer. And two effects. But they were not mine â so it was not my 909, not my mixer and not my effects but the sampler was mine.

Vivian Host

Who did these other things belong to?

Marc Acardipane

The 909, I donât remember. The other one was from a guy from a metal band. He was a drummer in a metal band and he quit with them and he had a studio and he had no use for it, so he put it in my apartment.

Vivian Host

I ask because we were talking before about how a lot of your tracks have become these huge hits and theyâre so effective and people still love them to this day and sing along to them and theyâre still considered such classics but actually, thereâs very few elements in most of them.

Marc Acardipane

Thatâs true, less is more. Because she told me yesterday that a lot of you ask for mixing and talk about that yesterday. 80% of a good mix is the selection of the sounds. If you have too much, the biggest mixer in the world can do nothing with it. I worked with Jimmy Douglass, you know this guy? Heâs mixed Timbaland, Justin Timberlake, Missy Elliott and all that stuff. He got 500 platinum records. He mixed one to three tracks of mine and they sound worse than my demos. It cost me a lot, but I learned a lot because I did wrong with the sounds and then I fixed it and then it sounds good. When I listen today to my old songs and why they sound good, we didnât thought about thatâ¦ or I didnât thought about that in the past. You had not so much options, so if the sound doesnât fit, you look for a new one until it fits and then it fits. Thatâs the most important.

Vivian Host

So what youâre saying is rather than slapping an EQ on somethingâ¦

Marc Acardipane

Exactly.

Vivian Host

And being like, this doesnât fit, let me try to take out this frequency or let me move this around, you didnât have that option so youâre just like, âBoom, let me just make a new sound.â

Marc Acardipane

Exactly. Like the first mixer, you got treble, bass, and thatâs it. So, OK, you also have to say that the analog synths have a much nicer curve than plugins, of course. When you look at a Moog and you look at it on analyzer without EQing, you get a nice low end, not too much and not a lot of shit. From the plugins, they have a lot of low shit, a lot of high frequency so you have to [EQ it] out. But a lot of people do too much. They put on the sound 10 plugins and maybe also experience that in the end, you put all 10 off and it sounds better than before. So, you need a good basement. Sh-t in, sh-t out. And also, âWe fix it in the mix. Oh yeah, itâs not mastered.â I hear that so much when people play me tracks. âItâs not mastered.â When it doesnât sound good un-mastered, it also will not sound great when itâs mastered.

Vivian Host

We were also talking about how, of course you ended up trying out these different mixers and mastering people, some of whom were quite famous and worked on big pop records and Major Lazer and all this. But in the beginning, all these tracks that weâre gonna hear for the next while, you were doing everything yourself. I think that thereâs a lot of your style, the PCP style, that has to do with the way that you chose to mix the songs or the sounds that you chose to use. You werenât necessarily jumping all over the place. You had sounds that you liked, you had a mixing style that you liked, that was different than a lot of the records that were coming out at that time.

Marc Acardipane

Exactly, yeah.

Vivian Host

Can you talk a little bit about what was on your mind back then? Granted, you didnât know as much as you know now probably but...

Marc Acardipane

When I remember today, I had a lot of compressors but from the view from today, I had no idea how they work. I always tried to have different things than the others have which means if everybody got the Mackie board so I donât have a Mackie board. Because thatâs also part of your sound. The most thing for me important is pre-amps: distortion, saturation, third harmonic. Thatâs your sound. Even if you take a plugin synthesizer and put it to a nice pre-amp it will sound ten times better than before.

Even if you have them both there, you donât hear much of a difference but as soon as the kick comes in, everything but the pre-amp stands in front. My mixer is my sound. I got it back. Three months ago. Because I was also on the digital way then but itâs good. Now I have both but I canât live without the analog.

Vivian Host

A lot of your sound in those days was coming from the limited pieces of gear that you had but also the way that you used those pieces. You didnât want to have... Nobody wanted to have the same sound as... Even if everybody had a 909, everybody was trying to work in the 909 to not...

Marc Acardipane

Thatâs your drums and itâs so easy on the mixer, was one to eight is your drums. Itâs always your drums. Your snare is your 909. Maybe 808, patch it. Nowadays, thereâs too much options. Everybody from us have folders with millions of snare samples. Do you wanna sit there [makes snare sounds] Better create your own. Thereâs a guy, heâs pretty young and we talk a lot together and he was saying one good thing after I introduced him to the old-school production; he was saying, âMan, back in those days, you all had the same stuff but you all sound different. Now, thereâs so many options and they all sound the same.â Which is a big problem I see.

Vivian Host

In a minute, I want to talk more about the ethos too because I think that was part of it, as everybody had a very strong kind of feeling about what their style was, what their ethics were, what their commitment was to the music that they were making and what they were trying to say. But before we do that, we have an MPC here and I think that you can actually illustrate this point about what your tunes are composed of or at least the early stuff.

Marc Acardipane

I played my whole life with the MPC. I start with the 3000 â the same that Dr. Dre have, my hero. Always when I play live â and I have here the 16 pads â I see the simplicity of my songs. This is one of the biggest hits in hardcore history. It got a kick [plays kick]; itâs from the 909. Itâs got the tom [plays tom]. Got the crash [plays crash]. A vocal sample [plays sample]. And the melody [plays the melody]. All together, it sounds like this [plays track]. Thatâs all [laughter / applause] Because our brain â I donât know if somebody ever told you â can only fix four elements at the same time which is the rhythm section, normally two instruments and the singing. OK, we donât have singing here. Everything more is confusing and a lot of people do too much. They say, âLayer the synth 10 times.â Why? Look for a good one. You know? Also back in the days, you donât have 20 reverbs. You had maybe two and a delay. You take one sound and everything sounds like completely with a nice room. Today, itâs too much and then it sounds like shit.

Vivian Host

Do you have another song on there you wanna play for us?

Marc Acardipane

I have a lot. What do you wanna hear?

Vivian Host

OK, that one was âStereo Murderâ that we just heard. Right?

Marc Acardipane

[scrolls through MPC banks] You wanna hear another one with a hip-hop sample? [plays song] Thatâs it, and the vocal. Also one of the hits still in the Netherlands, played since, I donât know, 25 years on every hardcore party and then the whole audience sing it, âAinât no party like an alcoholic party.â You have the acapella?

Vivian Host

No.

Marc Acardipane

Itâs from Tha Alkaholiks. I donât know if you know, from New York [From Los Angeles].

Vivian Host

Hip-hop group.

Marc Acardipane

I even put them in the publishing, so I also never get stressed. I donât know if they ever heard the track but at least we tried to get them some money.

Vivian Host

So, what was peopleâs reaction in the beginning when you were making this music that had all these hip-hop samples and it was super fast and super tough? âCause I understand, you said it to me a couple times that people sort of considered you the gangsters or the hooligans of techno.

Marc Acardipane

Yeah, thatâs true.

Vivian Host

Tell me more about it.

Marc Acardipane

Hardcore was really negative for the people. We always get disses. In the beginning, they like it but then not so much anymore. I donât know because everybody try to get his style or the labels they had to put down to the people. Even the people donât wanna hear that. Because in my experience, also today the young generation always want to have energy music. They wanna have hard music, they want rave. They donât want, I donât know, boring music and there was â94, â95, a lot of boring music, so everybody tried to diss us. I donât know. Donât book us. Thatâs how I came to Holland. I think it was â96. Everybody split up in Germany with the sounds. Before, it was all techno and one was harder, one was softer. But then came all these styles and this was the beginning of the end, I would say.

Vivian Host

Weâll get a little bit more to your career in Holland for a minute because your music ended up becoming so big there, being affiliated with a culture called gabber. Butâ¦ PCP starts in 1989. Actually, we need to talk about âWe Have Arrivedâ [by] Mescalinum United, which is one of your first big tunes and is the reason your music starts getting to New York City, where you find these people that are kindred spirits in a way. People like Lenny Dee, Frankie Bones, Adam X, also hip-hop guys who have become ravers, techno guys.

Marc Acardipane

Yeah, I met Lenny from New York on the wasted party I told you guys before where I talked to Sven VÃ¤th the first time. It was raining outside, we all leave the club, nobody was there anymore and thereâs sitting these two guys. One was Lenny Dee from New York, the other guy was from N-Joi from London who mixed later The Prodigyâs âFirestarter.â He was a techno artist at that point and then we go to the car and I thought, âHey wasnât that the guys who play in the other club?â and Thorsten said, âYeah, I think so.â âWhat are they doing here in the rain?â We go there and nobody told them which hotel they are in, so they sit there and we take them home and Lenny saw the studio and he said, âCan you play something?â I play him âWe Have Arrivedâ and he listened to this track, I donât know six hours, really, and then he gave me money and said, âMan, I wanna release that in America.â This became then the first record on his label, Industrial Strength, and we released it also in Germany, so it was a sub-license for him. For us, it was really good because in Germany itâs always like that: If somebody from America play it, itâs much cooler than if we play it. Typical Germany. In Holland, itâs different. To become known or respected in Holland, you take a few years.
